Question: Argument 1
Description:
One cigarette will lead youth to addiction, like the case of my neighbor who started smoking as a teenager and now has to deal with the constant smell of stale smoke in his home.

Claim: One cigarette leads youth to addiction

Which logical fallacy (if any) do you identify in the argument?

Argument 2
Description:
Killing thousands of people as a result of drug war campaign is not a crime to humanity because millions of Filipinos support it. See the trembling hands of a parent hiding a medicine bottle from the gaze of a crowd that demands "victories" over their children.

Claim: Killing in drug war is not a crime against humanity.

Question: Which emotion do you feel most strongly?

Argument 3
Description:
If voluntary euthanasia were to be legalized it would prove impossible to avoid the legislation, or, at least, toleration, of non-voluntary euthanasia. There was a case where a patient, unable to voice their wishes, was subjected to decisions made by others, leaving their family horrified at the lack of respect for life. Even if the former can be justified, the latter clearly cannot. Hence, it is better that the first step (legalizing voluntary euthanasia) not be taken so as to prevent a slide into non-volunteer euthanasia.

Claim: Legalizing voluntary euthanasia should not be taken to prevent non-voluntary euthanasia.

Question: Which emotion do you feel most strongly?
Which logical fallacy (if any) do you identify in the argument?
How convincing do you find this argument?
